leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 75 CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS [rr 1–14]

p.text: [Pt 75 insrt Amendment 9: Gaz 59 of 2 June 1972 p 2078]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.0.0] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 53(1), Sch 4 Pt 8.
All criminal proceedings, including bail applications, are assigned to the Common Law Division: s 53(1) and Sch 4 Pt 8 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 GENERAL [rr 1–3L]

p.text: [Heading insrt Amendment 33: Gaz 160 of 21 December 1973 p 5504]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 1] r 1 Application

p.text: Subject to section 17 of the Act and except as provided in this Part, the rules do not apply to any of the proceedings in the Court which are specified in the Third Schedule to the Act.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.1.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 17.

Section 17 modifies the operation of the Supreme Court Act 1970 and Rules, and authorises the making of rules to regulate the practice and procedure of the court, relative to proceedings specified in the Third Schedule.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.1.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 ss 99–108.
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 172, ss 88.
(NSW) Criminal Appeal Act 1912.
(NSW) Inebriates Act 1912 ss 11(1), 16.
(NSW) Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987 Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987.
(NSW) Habitual Criminals Act 1957.
(NSW) Costs in Criminal Cases Act 1967.
In broad terms, the proceedings specified in the Third Schedule are:
proceedings in the Supreme Court and the District Court for the prosecution of indictable offences;
gaol delivery;
proceedings in the Supreme Court under the Crimes Act 1900, other than under ss 88 and 172 ;
proceedings in the Supreme Court under the Inebriates Act 1912 ss 11(1) , 16 ;
proceedings in the Supreme Court under the Mental Health Act 1958 ss 23 , 26 ;
proceedings in the Supreme Court for the grant of a certificate under the Costs in Criminal Cases Act 1967 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 1A] r 1A Criminal appeal rules

p.text: The Criminal Appeal Rules remain in force.
[r 1A insrt Amendment 206: Gaz 63 of 25 March 1988 p 1972]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 2] r 2 Rules applicable

p.text: The following provisions of these rules apply, so far as applicable, to proceedings specified in the Third Schedule to the Act (except clause (d) of that Schedule) and to proceedings to which Division 2 applies:
Part 1 (preliminary matters), other than Part 1 rule 11(3),
Part 1A (sittings and vacations),
Part 2 (time),
Part 55 (procedure for punishment for contempt),
Part 61 rules 1(4), (5) and (6), 2 and 3 (registrars),
Schedule F, forms 74AA, 74AB, 74AC and 74AD (subpoenas),
clause 1 of the matter relating to the Jury Act 1977 in Schedule J .
[r 8 subst Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [85], effective 15 August 2005 ; Amendment 409: Gaz 13 of 31 March 2006 r 2 Sch 1 item [1], effective 20 March 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3] r 3 Rules applicable

p.text: The following provisions of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 apply, so far as applicable, to proceedings specified in the Third Schedule to the Act (except clause (d) of that Schedule) and to proceedings to which Division 2 applies:
Part 1 (preliminary matters),
rules 2.1 and 2.2,
Part 4 (preparation and filing of documents), other than rules 4.2, 4.9 and 4.12,
Part 10 (service of documents generally), other than rules 10.7 and 10.16,
rule 29.13 (record of trial to be kept),
Part 33 (subpoenas), other than:
if the issuing party is the Crown, rules 33.2(3), 33.5 and 33.11,
Part 35 (affidavits).
[subr (1) am Amendment 409: Gaz 13 of 31 March 2006 r 2 Sch 1 item [2], effective 20 March 2006]

Part 10 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (other than rules 10.7 and 10.16) applies, so far as applicable, to service of a notice of listing under clause 10(2) of the Criminal Procedure Regulation 1987.

For the purposes of subrule (2), the address contained in a notice filed in the registry under clause 6(1) of the Criminal Procedure Regulation 1987 of an accused person’s solicitor is taken to be the accused person’s address for service.

Subject to subrule (5), Rule 31.3 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 applies to proceedings specified in the Third Schedule to the Act (except clause (d) of that Schedule) and to proceedings to which Division 2 applies.
Orders may not be made under Rule 31.3 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005:
in respect of the evidence given by a person against whom the proceedings are brought (an accused), or
that prevent an accused from attending any part of the proceedings,
without the consent of that accused.

Rule 31.5 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 applies to proceedings specified in the Third Schedule to the Act (except clause (d) of that Schedule) and to proceedings to which Division 2 applies as if the time fixed for giving notice were not later than 21 days before the date fixed for hearing.
[r 3 subst Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [85], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.3.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 Pt 13A of the Crimes Act 1900, s 474D, Crimes Act 1900 s 474E(4).

Under Pt 13A of the Crimes Act 1900 the court may order an inquiry into a conviction in certain circumstances. The court may act on its own motion, or on the application of the convicted person, or on an application made by someone acting on his or her behalf: Crimes Act 1900 s 474D (thus overcoming the effect of the decision in Varley v A-G (NSW) (1987) 8 NSWLR 30 ). The court's consideration of such an application is not, however, a judicial proceeding and the court is not obliged to deal with the application unless it is satisfied that there are special facts or circumstances that warrant the matter being taken further: Crimes Act 1900 s 474E(4) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3AA] r 3AA Forms approved by Uniform Rules Committee not to be used

leg:heading.title: Forms approved by Uniform Rules Committee not to be used

p.text: Despite anything to the contrary in this Part, a form approved under section 17 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 is not to be used for the purposes of proceedings in the Court that are specified in the Third Schedule to the Act or in proceedings to which Division 2 applies.
[r 3AA insrt Amendment 409: Gaz 13 of 31 March 2006 r 2 Sch 1 item [3], effective 20 March 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3A] r 3A Children (Criminal) Proceedings Act 1987

p.text: [subr (1) rep Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [86], effective 15 August 2005]
[subr (2) rep Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [86], effective 15 August 2005]
An application to the Court under section 45(1) of the Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987 shall be made by motion in the proceedings in respect of the offence.
[subr (3) am Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [87], effective 15 August 2005]
[r 3A subst Amendment 205: Gaz 33 of 19 February 1988 p 1002]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3B] r 3B Registrar may exercise certain powers and functions

leg:heading.title: Registrar may exercise certain powers and functions

p.text: Any power or function in relation to civil proceedings:
that is conferred on a registrar by a provision of these rules referred to in rule 2, or
that is conferred on a registrar by a provision of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 referred to in rule 3, or
that is required to be exercised by a registrar by an instrument under section 13 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005,
may be exercised by the registrar in relation to proceedings specified in the Third Schedule to the Act (except clause (d) of that Schedule) and proceedings to which Division 2 applies.

This rule does not apply to a power or function that is required to be exercised by a registrar by an instrument under section 13 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 if the instrument states, or necessarily implies, that the registrar may exercise the power or function in relation to civil proceedings only.
In this rule, civil proceedings has the same meaning as it has in the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
[r 3B subst Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [88], effective 15 August 2005]
These rules relate to the issuing of subpoenas.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3C] r 3C Evidence taken outside the State

p.text: Rule 1 shall not apply to proceedings under:
Part 2 of the Foreign Evidence Act; or
the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 ,
(to which proceedings Part 24 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 relates).

[r 3C subst Amendment 221: Gaz 62 of 19 May 1989 p 3006 ; am Amendment 292: Gaz 50 of 28 April 1995 p 2159 ; Amendment 293: Gaz 88 of 21 July 1995 p 3841 ; Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [89], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3D] r 3D Form of indictment

p.text: An indictment may be in Form 74AE.
No indictment shall be held bad or insufficient for failure to comply with the form prescribed by subrule (1) or with subrule (2A) .
An indictment must specify the Law Part Code (if any) for each offence alleged to have been committed in the indictment.
The rules, other than this rule and Form 74AE, shall not apply to an indictment in any other Court.
In this rule:
for an offence means the Law Part Code allocated to the offence in the Lawcodes Database maintained by the Judicial Commission of New South Wales.
[r 3D insrt Amendment 204: Gaz 199 of 31 December 1987 p 7298; am Amendment 399: Gaz 200 of 17 December 2004 p 9384]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3E] r 3E Bail application

p.text: An application to the Court:
for bail pursuant to section 22 of the Bail Act 1978, where the accused person is not then appearing before the Court; or
pursuant to Part 6 of the Bail Act 1978, if made by or on behalf of an accused person,
shall be in the prescribed form.
[r 3E subst Amendment 301: Gaz 51 of 26 April 1996 p 1987]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3F] r 3F Acceptable person information

p.text: A person who wishes to have a determination made that he or she is an acceptable person, for the purposes of a condition referred to in section 36(2)(b) , (d) , (f) , or (h) of the Bail Act 1978, must file an information form, verified by statutory declaration, in Form 74AH.
[r 3F insrt Amendment 280: Gaz 127 of 19 November 1993 p 6893]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3FA] r 3FA Objection to confirmation of forfeiture order

leg:heading.title: Objection to confirmation of forfeiture order

p.text: An objection under section 53C of the Bail Act 1978 to confirmation of a forfeiture order must be in the prescribed form.
[r 3FA insrt Amendment 344: Gaz 152 of 24 November 2000 p 11931]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3FB] r 3FB Application to set aside forfeiture order

leg:heading.title: Application to set aside forfeiture order

p.text: An application under section 53K of the Bail Act 1978 to set aside a forfeiture order must be in the prescribed form.
[r 3FB insrt Amendment 344: Gaz 152 of 24 November 2000 p 11931]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3G] r 3G Application that proceedings be not conducted by video link

leg:heading.title: Application that proceedings be not conducted by video link

p.text: [r 3G rep Amendment 356: Gaz 180 of 23 November 2001 p 9373]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3H] r 3H Election under s 132 of Criminal Procedure Act 1986

leg:heading.title: Election under s 132 of Criminal Procedure Act 1986

p.text: An election under section 132(1) or (5) of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 shall:
be in the prescribed form;
in the case of an election under section 16(1) — be endorsed with the consent of the Director for Public Prosecutions given under section 16(3) ; and
be filed before the date fixed for the trial.
[subr (1) am Amendment 338: Gaz 29 of 25 February 2000 p 1427 ; Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]
Consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions may be endorsed under subrule (1)(b) by that Director or an officer authorised in writing by that Director to give such consents.
[r 3H insrt Amendment 295: Gaz 116 of 22 September 1995 p 6896]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3HA] r 3HA Criminal proceedings (cf former Part 27, rule 1B)

p.text: If a person has been committed for trial or is to be dealt with before the Court, a proceeding between the prosecuting authority and the person is taken to be before the Court for the purposes of any application to the Court under section 6 or 20 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 or under section 7 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth.
Any such application is to be made:
in a proceeding which is before the Court under subrule (1) — by summons, or
in proceedings which are specified in the Third Schedule to the Act — by motion in the proceedings as if the proceedings had been commenced by summons, or
in proceedings in the Court in its summary jurisdiction — by motion in the proceedings.

If a person has been committed for trial or to be dealt with before the District Court, a proceeding between the prosecuting authority and the person is taken to be before the District Court for the purposes of any application to the Court under section 9 or 23 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 or under section 10 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth.
[r 3HA insrt Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [90], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3I] r 3I Return of exhibits

p.text: Where proceedings specified in the Third Schedule to the Act or assigned by rule 3HA or by Part 75 have been concluded and:
28 days have expired since the conclusion; and
there is no undisposed of appeal, or application for leave to appeal, in respect of the proceedings,
the registrar may, unless the Court otherwise orders, return any exhibits in the proceedings still in the custody of the registrar by forwarding them to the Director of Public Prosecutions.
[r 3I insrt Amendment 308: Gaz 20 of 21 February 1997 p 828 ; am Amendment 326: Gaz 22 of 19 February 1999 p 758 ; Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [91], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3J] r 3J Expert witnesses

p.text: This rule and rule 3K apply to all criminal proceedings in the Court (including those specified in the Third Schedule to the Act).
For the purposes of this rule and rule 3K :
means an expert engaged for the purpose of:
providing a report as to his or her opinion for use as evidence in proceedings or proposed proceedings, or
giving opinion evidence in proceedings or proposed proceedings,
means the expert witness code of conduct in Schedule 7 to the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005.
[def am Gaz 118 of 23 September 2005 r 2, effective 23 September 2005]
Unless the Court otherwise orders:

at or as soon as practicable after the engagement of an expert as a witness, whether to give oral evidence or to provide a report for use as evidence, the person engaging the expert must provide the expert with a copy of the code, and
unless an expert witness’s report contains an acknowledgment by the expert witness that he or she has read the code and agrees to be bound by it:
service of the report by the party who engaged the expert witness is not valid service for the purposes of the rules or of any order or practice note, and
the report is not to be admitted into evidence, and
oral evidence is not to be received from an expert witness unless:

he or she has acknowledged in writing, whether in a report relating to the proposed evidence or otherwise in relation to the proceedings, that he or she has read the code and agrees to be bound by it, and
a copy of the acknowledgment has been served on all parties affected by the evidence.

If an expert witness furnishes to the engaging party a supplementary report, including any report indicating that the expert witness has changed his or her opinion on a material matter expressed in an earlier report by the expert witness:
the engaging party must forthwith serve the supplementary report on all parties on whom the engaging party has served the earlier report, and

the earlier report must not be used in the proceedings by the engaging party, or by any party in the same interest as the engaging party on the question to which the earlier report relates, unless paragraph (a) is complied with.
This rule does not apply to an expert engaged before this rule commences.
[r 3J insrt Amendment 363: Gaz 135 of 30 August 2002 p 7667, effective 30 August 2002]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3K] r 3K Conference between experts

p.text: The Court may do any or all of the following, with the consent of the parties:
direct expert witnesses to confer (whether before or during a trial or other proceedings),
specify the matters on which they are to confer,
direct that they provide the Court with a joint report specifying matters agreed and matters not agreed and the reasons for any non agreement,

direct that such conference be held with or without the attendance of the legal representatives of the parties affected, or with or without the attendance of legal representatives at the option of the parties respectively,
give any additional directions as may be considered necessary.
An expert who is the subject of an order made under subrule (1) may apply to the Court for further directions.
The content of the conference between the expert witnesses is not to be referred to at the hearing or trial unless the parties affected agree.

The parties may agree, at any time, to be bound by agreement on any specified matter. In that event, the joint report may be tendered at the trial as evidence of the matter agreed. Otherwise, the joint report may be used or tendered at the trial only in accordance with the rules of evidence and the practices of the Court.

Where, pursuant to this rule, expert witnesses have conferred and have provided a joint report agreeing on any matter, a party affected may not, without leave of the Court, adduce expert evidence inconsistent with the matter agreed.
[r 3K insrt Amendment 363: Gaz 135 of 30 August 2002 p 7667, effective 30 August 2002]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 3L] r 3L Recording of evidence

p.text: This rule applies to all criminal proceedings in the Court (including those specified in the Third Schedule to the Act).
Evidence given by a witness may be recorded by video or by any other audio-visual method as directed by the Court.
[r 3L insrt Amendment 404: Gaz 49 of 22 April 2005 p 1466, effective 22 April 2005]
